properties.description: Not Applicable (no global hypothesis specified for this run)
Defeat of France in the French and Indian War
British Parliament imposed new taxes to compensate for wartime costs
British officials in Montreal turned control of the colonies' western lands over to British officials
Grenville ministry issued the Royal Proclamation of 1763, designating western territory as Indian Reserve closed to white settlement
Parliament passed the Sugar Act, decreasing duties but increasing enforcement
Grenville proposed direct taxes on the colonies to raise revenue
Parliament passed the Stamp Act, imposing first direct taxes
Representatives from several colonies convened the Stamp Act Congress
Stamp Act Congress drew up a Declaration of Rights and Grievances
Stamp Act Congress organized a boycott on imports of all British merchandise
Shortly following adoption of the Stamp Act, the Sons of Liberty formed
Sons of Liberty used public demonstrations, boycotts, and threats of violence
In Boston, the Sons of Liberty looted the home of chief justice Thomas Hutchinson
In Boston, the Sons of Liberty burned the records of the vice admiralty court
Parliament repealed the Stamp Act
Parliament passed the Declaratory Act asserting full power to legislate for colonies
British Parliament passed the Townshend Acts, placing duties on goods and establishing customs board
Colonists responded to Townshend Acts taxes by organizing new boycotts of British goods
Assembly of Massachusetts Bay Colony issued a circular letter urging coordinated resistance
Governor dissolved the Massachusetts assembly for refusing to rescind the circular letter
Riot broke out in Boston over the seizure of the sloop Liberty
Customs officials were forced to flee Boston after the Liberty riot
British troops deployed to Boston following the Liberty riot
Parliament reactivated the Treason Act 1543 targeting colonists
British soldiers fired into a crowd, killing 5 civilians
Lord North's ministry repealed most Townshend duties, except the tax on tea
American patriots burned the British warship HMS Gaspee
Private letters of Governor Hutchinson claiming colonists couldn't enjoy all English liberties were published
Published letters discredited Hutchinson in the eyes of the people
Colonial Assembly petitioned for Hutchinson's recall
Benjamin Franklin acknowledged leaking letters and was removed from postmaster position
Samuel Adams set about creating new Committees of Correspondence linking patriots
Parliament passed the Tea Act lowering price of taxed tea and appointing consignees
Consignees for tea sales were forced by Americans to resign in most colonies
Boston town meeting determined tea would not be landed and ignored governor's demand to disperse
Group led by Samuel Adams dumped tea into Boston Harbor
British government responded to Boston Tea Party by passing four Intolerable Acts
Massachusetts Government Act altered the Massachusetts charter and restricted town meetings
Administration of Justice Act ordered British soldiers to be tried in Britain
Boston Port Act closed the port of Boston until compensated for tea
Quartering Act of 1774 allowed royal governors to house British troops in homes
Massachusetts patriots issued the Suffolk Resolves
Massachusetts patriots formed an alternative shadow government known as the Provincial Congress
Provincial Congress began training militia outside British-occupied Boston
First Continental Congress convened with representatives from 12 colonies
First Continental Congress called for a boycott of all British goods starting December 1, 1774
Local committees authorized by Congress enforced the boycott, examining records and publishing names
American Revolutionary War launched in the Battles of Lexington and Concord
Second Continental Congress convened
Second Continental Congress formed the Continental Army
Second Continental Congress appointed George Washington commander-in-chief
Washington and the Continental Army responded to battles by surrounding Boston
British forces forced to withdraw from Boston by sea
Patriots in control in every colony
King George III proclaimed Massachusetts to be in a state of open defiance and rebellion
Second Continental Congress began debating and deliberating on the Articles of Confederation
Second Continental Congress passed the Lee Resolution affirming support for independence
Second Continental Congress unanimously adopted the Declaration of Independence
France ultimately entered the war, supporting the colonial cause
Washington led the Continental Army's most decisive victory, capturing British troops at Yorktown
Siege of Yorktown led to the collapse of King George's control of Parliament
Siege of Yorktown led to consensus in Parliament that the war should be ended on American terms
The British signed the Treaty of Paris, granting independence and territory
British acknowledge independence of the United States
United States became the first constitutional republic in world history founded on the consent of the governed and the rule of law
About 60,000 Loyalists migrated to other British territories
British policy of salutary neglect towards the colonies (1651-1763)
Colonists became accustomed to running their own affairs
British national debt had grown significantly by 1763
Need for money played a part in every important British decision regarding the colonies
Decision to permanently garrison 10,000 soldiers in North America
Principle that taxation without representation violates rights
Radical Whig ideology profoundly influenced American political philosophy (love of liberty, opposition to tyranny)
British government pursued a policy of mercantilism, viewing colonies for economic benefit
Series of Navigation Acts restricting colonial trade with foreign countries (started 1651)
Existence of colonial militias with military experience

properties.description: Mechanism of colonial opposition to British policies using political and economic means.
Mechanism by which colonial patriots organized and coordinated action across colonies.
Mechanism describing the reciprocal increase in tensions and actions between Britain and the colonies.
Mechanism describing British efforts to assert authority and control over the colonies.
British argument that colonists were 'virtually represented' in Parliament like most British subjects, justifying taxation without direct colonial representatives.
Quote from Capt. Levi Preston explaining the reason for rebellion.
Content of the Declaration of Rights and Grievances stating taxation without representation violated rights.
Actions by Sons of Liberty (demonstrations, boycotts, threats) making tax laws unenforceable.
Looting of Thomas Hutchinson's home by Sons of Liberty.
Burning of vice admiralty court records by Sons of Liberty.
Argument in 'Letters from a Farmer in Pennsylvania' against constitutionality of Townshend Acts taxes aimed at revenue.
Content of Massachusetts Circular Letter urging coordinated resistance.
Details of the riot over the seizure of the sloop Liberty.
Details of the Boston Massacre incident.
Details of the burning of HMS Gaspee.
Content of Hutchinson's private letters claiming colonists couldn't enjoy all English liberties.
Existence and function of the Committees of Correspondence network linking patriots.
Actions of local committees enforcing the boycott (examining records, publishing names).
Provisions of the Tea Act (lowering price, appointing consignees).
Reports of tea consignees being forced to resign in most colonies.
Details of the Boston Tea Party (dumping tea, value).
Provisions of the four Intolerable Acts (Massachusetts Gov't Act, Admin of Justice Act, Boston Port Act, Quartering Act).
Issuance of the Suffolk Resolves.
Formation of the Massachusetts Provincial Congress.
Reports of militia training outside Boston.
Meeting of the First Continental Congress.
Calling for the Continental Association boycott.
Details of the Battles of Lexington and Concord.
Formation of the Continental Army and appointment of George Washington.
British withdrawal from Boston in March 1776.
Content and adoption of the Declaration of Independence.
Entry of France into the Revolutionary War.
Outcome of the Siege of Yorktown (capture of British troops).
Terms of the Treaty of Paris (independence, territory).
Reported number of Loyalists migrating after the war (~60,000).

properties.source_text_quote: 'Declaration of Rights and Grievances' argued that taxation without representation violated their rights as Englishmen.
"…we always had governed ourselves, and we always meant to. They didn’t mean we should."
Sons of Liberty formed, and began using public demonstrations, boycotts, and threats of violence to ensure that the British tax laws became unenforceable.
In Boston, the Sons of Liberty... looted the home of chief justice Thomas Hutchinson.
In Boston, the Sons of Liberty burned the records of the vice admiralty court...

However, in his widely read pamphlet, Letters from a Farmer in Pennsylvania, John Dickinson argued against the constitutionality of the acts because their purpose was to raise revenue and not to regulate trade.
the Assembly of Massachusetts Bay Colony issued a circular letter to the other colonies urging them to coordinate resistance.
Meanwhile, a riot broke out in Boston in June 1768 over the seizure of the sloop Liberty, owned by John Hancock, for alleged smuggling.
On March 5, 1770, a large crowd gathered... soldiers panicked and fired into the crowd. They hit 11 people; three civilians died...
In June 1772, American patriots, including John Brown, burned a British warship... in what became known as the Gaspee Affair.
In 1773, private letters were published in which Massachusetts Governor Thomas Hutchinson claimed that the colonists could not enjoy all English liberties...
In Boston, Samuel Adams set about creating new Committees of Correspondence, which linked Patriots in all 13 colonies and eventually provided the framework for a rebel government.
When the First Continental Congress decided to boycott British products, the colonial and local Committees took charge, examining merchant records and publishing the names of merchants...
Meanwhile, Parliament passed the Tea Act lowering the price of taxed tea exported to the colonies, to help the British East India Company undersell smuggled untaxed Dutch tea.
On December 16, 1773, a group of men... boarded the ships... and dumped £10,000 worth of tea... into Boston Harbor.
The British government responded by passing four laws that came to be known as the Intolerable Acts...
In response, Massachusetts patriots issued the Suffolk Resolves...
...and formed an alternative shadow government known as the Provincial Congress...
...which began training militia outside British-occupied Boston.
In September 1774, the First Continental Congress convened...
Congress called for a boycott beginning on December 1, 1774, of all British goods...
The revolution culminated in the American Revolutionary War, which was launched on April 19, 1775, in the Battles of Lexington and Concord.
The Second Continental Congress... formed the Continental Army and appointed George Washington as its commander-in-chief in June 1775...
Following the Battles of Lexington and Concord, Washington and the Continental Army responded by surrounding Boston, forcing the British to withdraw by sea in March 1776...
...on July 4, 1776, they unanimously adopted the Declaration of Independence, authored primarily by Thomas Jefferson...
The Revolutionary War continued for another five years during which France ultimately entered the war, supporting the colonial cause of independence.
On September 28, 1781, Washington... led the Continental Army's most decisive victory, capturing roughly 7,500 British troops led by British general Charles Cornwallis during the Siege of Yorktown...
On September 3, 1783, the British signed the Treaty of Paris, granting their former colonies nearly all the territory east of the Mississippi River...
About 60,000 Loyalists migrated to other British territories in Canada and elsewhere...
